content: I couldn’t have said it better myself. Thank you for writing this very important piece. I get some reprieve from the nosy, judging questions because (I believe) I only have use of one hand (a whole other thing; I think that people assume that I don’t have children because I couldn’t take care of them with my disability, which isn’t necessarily true.) But in reality I’ve never felt the need or desire to be a mother, despite enjoying children and spending time around them. I started saying this in high school, and I was told I’d change my mind. I haven’t. Before the disabilities were a factor, I found myself answering questions about not having kids and being accused of being selfish, and it’s not something I miss. I have couple friends that are childless-by-choice that tell me that they get asked when they’re having kids, or why haven’t they had kids yet, all the time, and it seems to me the height of presumption — there could numerous reasons why a couple wouldn’t want to talk about that (besides the fact that it isn’t anyone’s business.) The assumption that people want to talk about this personal matter with anyone and everyone makes me angry. There are plenty of kids in my life that need a strong, caring adult female figure (some as many as they can get!) I am very happy to be that for them. I don’t feel like I need a child of my own. Great article.
